description.en-US: Full-width container for creating visually distinct Calls-to-Action (CTAs).

content.value: A CTA banner highlights a single message with a call to action button or link. The content of the banner may be critical, important or informational. While the CTA banner can appear anywhere on the page, we recommend it is used towards the end of the page.

We made all the fields in the CTA banner component optional to ensure that editors can adopt it for a wide range of use cases. For example, should the editor publish the component without the copy and target page, it will show up on a page as a visual element rendered with the background of the editor's choice.
Content modeling considerations

Keep in mind that when it comes to linking to the target page we chose to use the reference field configured to work solely with Page entries. This was done to avoid errors coming from mistyped URLs. Our customers could have a free-form URL field instead.
Component styling options
The design of the website components allows editors to change the color of the component by choosing from the list of pre-defined styles:
By default, the component is rendered with the white background.

description.en-US: Full-width container for displaying side-by-side image and copy.

content.value: This component is the workhorse of our design because it allows editors to mix and match images and words. It is one of the most frequently used components on the landing and product pages.

The Duplex component comes with a number of layout and style options baked into it. This allows editors to reuse the component on the page, without slipping into visual fatigue. For example, editors can highlight the component on the page by setting it to a contrasting color or give the page a natural visual flow by alternating the position of the image from left to right.
Container layout options
This setting determines the position of the image relative to the text:
Image on the left
: the image will be displayed on the left side of the copy paragraph (or above the copy paragraph where the page is resized to fit on a narrow display)
Image on the right
: the image will be displayed on the right side of the paragraph (or below the copy paragraph where the page is resized to fit on a narrow display)
If editor fails to choose a layout option, the component will default to the image on the left when the entry is published.
Image style options
This setting determines the height of the image within the component container:
Fixed height
: the image will occupy the middle part of the container with a default margin at the top and the bottom of the image. This is by far the most preferred option when publishing editorial images.
Full height

: the image will occupy the entire height of the container, there are no margins at the top of the bottom of the image. This option should be used when using images that rely on oversize effect (e.g. a hand holding up a phone, a person peeking out from behind the wall, etc.)
By default, the component renders image with a fixed height.
Image alignment options
This setting determines the alignment of the image within the container:
Center-aligned
: the image is aligned to the center of the container
Left-aligned
: the image is aligned to the left side of the container
Right-aligned
: the image is aligned to the right side of the container
By default, the component aligns the image to the center of the component.
Component styling options
The design of the website components allows editors to change the color of the component by choosing from the list of pre-defined styles:
By default, the component is rendered with the white background.

description.en-US: Brand colors and how/when to use them

content.value: A preview of our brand colors:
When to use each shade?

Although we value an aesthetically pleasing use of color, we place a higher
value on clear communication. Our use of color should be purposeful, rational,
and should serve to support the purpose of the content.

description.en-US: Component enabling product presentation in a table

content.value: The Product table component provides a visual illustration of how editors can effectively create content work in a tabular layout without resorting to the use of tables in the editor.

The component takes as its inputs 1 to 3 product entries and arranges them side-by-side, in a long table. This type of layout is great for pricing pages, but you can also use to provide product comparison on any other page. Note that shuffling the products in the reference field also changes their position in the table.

The component has an optional Headline and Subline fields for introducing the section on the page. Unlike the rest of components, the Product table does not have styling options. Since the component is visually complex, introducing further visual options would have complicated the authoring workflow and from time to time result in a Frankenstein module on the page. So we kept it simple.
How it works

The Product table component stands out from other components, because in addition to visual rendering it does some content manipulation behind the scenes. The Colorful Coin website offers detailed information about its products on the Product and Pricing pages. While the core content is the same, the purpose of these pages is different: the Product page should provide in-depth descriptions and detailed discussion of each feature, while the Pricing page should provide a lightweight overview of key features.
Maintaining two separate content types for these purposes would have been confusing, which is why we settled on the idea of having a single content type to capture
all
the product-related information in one place. But when it comes to displaying that information, we grab the
Long feature description
field for the Product page template and the
Short feature description
for the Product table component. This way, editors only need to publish entry once and we show the right content in the right context.

description.en-US: A collection of cards used to promote editorial content throughout the website.

content.value: This component provides an easy way to curate and promote existing blog posts throughout the demo website. The posts you reference from within the Featured cards entry will be rendered as cards featuring a thumbnail, blog post title, and a click-through link to the post.

The Featured cards component should be used on the blog post page to promote related posts and on the marketing website, where it makes sense to highlight the blog content. Keep in mind that you need to provide 2-3 posts for the component to work visually.
Component styling options
The design of the website components allows editors to change the color of the component by choosing from the list of pre-defined styles:
By default, the component is rendered with the white background.

description.en-US: Component for displaying ad-hoc text copy.

content.value: Whenever you need to include a longer passage on your landing / product page that falls outside of the existing topics (e.g. products, features, authors), you can use the Text Block component.
The component includes optional fields for Headline and Subline, which can be used to introduce the section on the page.
Best practices

To keep things flexible, we've used the Rich text editor (RTE) for the copy field. The RTE comes with all the standard features included, allowing editors to embed assets and reference other entries from within this component.

Keep in mind that this component is meant for localized, ephemeral content consumed within a specific channel. If you find yourself coming back to this component on a regular basis, you would be better off revising your content model to include a new type of topic.
Component styling options
The design of the website components allows editors to change the color of the component by choosing from the list of pre-defined styles:
By default, the component is rendered with the white background.

description.en-US: Full-width component for quotes, reviews and testimonials.

content.value: While the purpose of this component is very simple, we have baked multiple visual options into it to support a wide range of design needs.

The component comes equipped with the Rich text editor (RTE), which keeps it flexible without overwhelming the editor. For example, since the Quote component is meant to be used for short, streamlined content, we have removed some of the styling options (bullets, headings, line breaks) from the editor.
Use of images
There are two ways to add images to the Quote component:
The dedicated image field should be used for editorial images. When such an image is used, the editors can also decide on the position of the image relative to the quote.

To decorate the quote with logos, icons, profile shots and other small-scale visual elements, please use the "Embed Asset" feature in the rich text editor. Such elements will be aligned to the center of the container, but editors can decide on whether they should be displayed above, in the middle, or below the copy of the quote.
Quote alignment
The component comes with two options for aligning the copy of the quote:
Center-aligned
: the quote will be aligned to the center of the container. This option works great for quotes that don't use editorial images.
Left-aligned
: the quote will be aligned to the left of the container. This option is recommended for quotes that incorporate editorial images.
Component styling options
The design of the website components allows editors to change the color of the component by choosing from the list of pre-defined styles:
By default, the component is rendered with the white background.

description.en-US: Full-width container for displaying visual content and marketing copy; includes an optional CTA.

content.value: The hero banner is used to add visual appeal to the page and/or summarize its content. It can also be styled a number of different ways to match the content and purpose of the page it introduces and it can contain a Call-to-action (CTA) that enables the visitor to make the next step.
Adding a CTA

The Hero component is set up to provide maximum flexibility for editors. Whenever the editor adds copy to the CTA text field, it will be rendered as a CTA button. If the editor publishes the component without providing a target page, the CTA button will be inactive.

The Target page field is set up as a reference field and accepts only Page type entries. This ensures that the CTA button always leads visitors to a valid page on the demo website. The downside of this approach is that the editor cannot add a URL or append custom variables to an existing page to track the traffic coming from a specific button.

We made our decision to go with the reference field rather than a URL field assuming that it's more important to reduce the number of errors in the demo instance than accurately track visitor journeys. Content architects in charge of building production website might prioritize other things and therefore choose to build this component in a different way.
Image style options
This setting determines the width of the background image in the container:
Partial background

: the component will reveal the right side of the background image only, the left side of the container will be overlaid on the background image to provide a high-contrast area for the hero copy. This option should be used when the background image is visually bright/ eclectic/ diffuse and it affects the readability of the text.
Full background
: the component will reveal the entire background image. This is the standard option and should be used most of the time.
By default, the component will reveal the entire background image.
Component styling options
The design of the website components allows editors to change the color of the component by choosing from the list of pre-defined styles:
By default, the component is rendered with the white background.

description.en-US: Full-width container for displaying short bits of generic information with optional icons/visuals.

content.value: The component is meant to be used for advertising product benefits or outlining generic steps in a process. While the component is built to work with assets, you should only use small scale visuals here (think icons, logos, numbers).
The info block is designed to have a maximum of 3 items (though editors can also use it with 1/2 items). It can also have a headline and subline introducing the benefits.
Best practices

To keep things flexible, we've used the Rich text editor (RTE) for the copy field. However, we’ve paired down the number of available formatting options and disabled the possibility to embed assets and entries, because the component is meant to be used for short snippets of content.

Sometimes editors would need to introduce more than 3 benefits/features on the page. In this case, they can combine several Info block components to build up a grid of a desired height. In this scenario, the first entry typically includes a headline introducing the section, whereas follow-up entries only contain individual benefits.
Content model considerations

Rather than rely on the reference field, this component has dedicated fields for all three items. The intention here was to demonstrate how a fixed assembly component looks like. You can compare that with the setup of the Topic product/Topic product feature, where we use a reference field and an additional type to streamline authoring workflow.
Component styling options
The design of the website components allows editors to change the color of the component by choosing from the list of pre-defined styles:
By default, the component is rendered with the white background.

description.en-US: Topic for holding info about people.

content.value: This versatile topic is used for holding personal bios of people referenced throughout the website. These could include authors of blog posts, company leadership, customers providing testimonials, guests profiled on marketing pages and more.
Card style options
The Person topic has card style option to determine how the personal bio should be displayed on the page:
Regular card
: the default option to be used across the website; displays the social media link and renders the person card in a compact way.
Leader profile
: the option to be used when featuring leaders in the body of the page; omits the social media link and displays the persona card in a full-width style complementing the body content style.
By default, the component renders personal information as a regular card.

description.en-US: A catch-all topic for generic business content like About us, Career, FAQ and more.

content.value: The Business info topic allows editors create pages with generic business information. To create such a page, the editors first needs to populate the topic entry with content and then attach it to a desired page using the Page content field.

To keep things flexible, we've used the Rich text editor (RTE) for the copy field. The RTE comes with all the standard features included, allowing editors to embed assets and reference other entries from within this component.

Notice that pages powered by the Business info topic by default are rendered with the header using black background & white font color. This is done to ensure a consistent style across the website. When the featured images is available, it is displayed instead of the black background. To ensure legibility, we recommend using dark images for the featured image field.

description.en-US: Product feature component enables reuse of generic features across different products.

content.value: Product feature component is used together with the Topic Product component to streamline the management of individual product features. This way, editors can use a single entry to represent the same feature in multiple products. Relying on the reference field to attach features to a product also allows editors easily shuffle the order of features to achieve the desired flow of content on the page.
Best Practices

Notice that the content type has fields for the Short description and Long description. The idea is that we use the short description when a feature is being displayed in a product comparison table and the long one on the actual product page. This small trick allows editors to re-use products across different presentational contexts without having to worry about text overruns.
Note that when the Short description field is left empty, the component defaults to displaying the content from the Long description field.

description.en-US: Container for product-specific information like card definitions, features, benefits, prices & more.

content.value: Topic entries form a part of the Topics & Assemblies publishing pattern and are great for storing reusable content. Below you can see how this content is rendered in the context of a website page. The advantage of this approach is that the editors only needs to fill out the entry forms, while the code does all the heavy-lifting by laying out and formatting the content.
Content modeling considerations

Note that we decided to add product features as a sub-content-type to enable re-use of feature descriptions across products. The benefit of this approach is that generic features can be updated with one click and it's easier for editors to keep website content up-to-date. If you plan to use features across multiple products, however, remember to name them appropriately to avoid confusion in the future.

description.en-US: Blog category enabling visitors to filter blog posts by topic.

content.value: This content type allows editors to add custom categories to the blog post. Available categories are displayed at the top of the blog feed and, when clicked, pull in all the blog posts tagged with a given category.

description.en-US: All-in-one content type for publishing blog posts.

content.value: We explicitly modeled our blog entries in the mould of more page-centric CMS systems to enable editors create blog posts in a familiar way.

The blog post content type uses a rich text field for the main content, which means that you can embed all kinds of components and assets in the main text opening a possibility to do very creative things there (insert customer quotes, add videos, embed Spotify playlists, etc.).

For those looking to customize the standard layout of the blog post, use the Extra section field to add the desired component -- for example, a blog teaser or a CTA banner -- to the bottom of the page. We do not allow custom components to be added to the top of the blog post to preserve the original layout.

description.en-US: Container that enables editors to publish a page, define its slug, select & arrange its content.

content.value: Pages are probably the most used content type on the website. Whenever you want to publish a new page, you have to start by creating a new Page entry and populating it with the right content.

We do not provide the illustration of this content type, because each page is unique: the look and layout of the page will be determined by individual components and topics that the editor will chose to add to the page.
Here is an overview of three distinct possibilities for creating pages:
Version A
. To publish a page with predefined layout (Business info page, Product page), attach a relevant entry to the
Page content
field. The code will automatically render the topic in the right layout on the frontend.
Version B
. You can customize the page with predefined layout further by inserting desired components above or below the main content. Use the
Top section
field to add them above the main content and
Extra section
to add below.
Version C
. You can also skip main content altogether and populate the page solely with visual components. This works great for landing pages and other ad-hoc content. Use either
Top section/Extra section
to insert desired content into the page and leave the
Page content
field blank.
Please note that to publish a page you need to provide the following information:
Page name
Slug
Meta description

We use these fields to populate the Open Graph (OG) meta tags for the page. These are the tags that determine what shows up on a preview card when you share the link to the page on social media. So by authoring these fields you can determine how your page will be previewed on websites like LinkedIn, Twitter, and Facebook.
When the page is missing content or attached content does not include a featured image, we use a fallback image for OG tags.

description.en-US: This is how you present the jackets
